column5: Thatâ€™s why I was confused at first, followed by all of the Norwegian!

I got kicked in the face in boot camp because of a moron in front of me! 

â€œHalf Right, FACEâ€
â€œFront Lean and Rest Position, MOVE!â€

One jackass took his time getting down...

â€œGet up!â€
â€œGet down!â€

Asshole Jamaican dude (fact, not racist) in front of me, who was why we were playing these fuck fuck games, kept inching backwards to me. I kept trying to whisper to move forward. He was stupid. What turned out to be the last, â€œGet down!â€, ended in my getting kicked just below the eye. Iâ€™m pissed. We push. Then the DS isnâ€™t done so he never orders, â€œRECOVER!â€. We remain in the Front Lean and Rest position. Something is tickling my skin. My head drops down and blood ğŸ©¸ drips onto the pavement, then begins to pour. We recover and Iâ€™m completely covered in my blood, down my neck and into my brown t-shirt. DS notices immediately and freaks the fuck out! Heâ€™s screaming at the moron. Iâ€™m sent to the back of the formation to be checked out by our Jr DS. I tell him what happened, asks me if I needed medical and I declined. â€œI can see boot polish in the cut, when we get back to the barracks you HAVE to get that out.â€ Lazy ass wouldnâ€™t even get the clumps of Kiwi out of the crevice in the boot sole! We go back and ALL we were allowed to have was Isopropyl Alcohol. I had to have two guys take turns digging that douche bags boot polish from my cut using only Q-Tips and Isopropyl Alcohol! 

Until my face healed I was pulled out of formation by EVERY officer and Senior NCO that passed by. My DS (junior one) and I knew before the officer/SNCO did that we needed to fall out. Our Senior DS kept marching the formation like this was normal (because by then it was).

Moral: donâ€™t be a dick. Be aware of your surroundings.

He rented a room from an old woman when he was doing a lot of work in NC (we lived in Virginia). Heâ€™s in the room going through negatives and paperwork on the bed and doses off. Uniforms can literally be a specific color/style without holes. Example: Delta Forceâ€™s first official mission was in 1979 attempting to rescue the US Embassy hostages that were taken by angry â€˜college studentsâ€™ in Tehran. The mission failed horribly and a lot was learned. However, their â€™uniformsâ€™ consisted of blue jeans, a black wool watch cap (beanie/ski cap) and a field jacket dyed black.

Uniforms can be, black non-slip shoes (like what most entry jobs require), khaki pants/shorts and a shirt. The point of the â€˜uniformâ€™ is NOT to pretend to look like the military, but to look like each other, Including brand! Though I DO agree with uniforms, but not adopted from the military (maybe dress uniforms for special occasions/functions). Remember, prisoners wear uniforms also. The most important part of the uniform is to be the same (especially brand!), something most kids can afford. Secondly, in my opinion it should be most importantly, it teaches pride in themselves and attention to detail. I can go on, but I think this is enough to ponder...?

I say, â€œSave a kid, screw a recruiter!â€

I was in the Army and then the Navy. Teach them about jobs (MOSâ€™s/Rates), what they ACTUALLY do, what they teach you and how it translates to the civilian world. One of my favorites was from the Navy, Hull Technician (HT). The recruiter sells the rate as being a â€œwelderâ€. They are confused about why there was no welding in the A school and why they are called â€˜turd chasersâ€™. Then they get to the boat. They are basically Plumbers Apprentices for their career. Most ships are small so the welding billet goes to a First Class, HT1 (E-6). Even on a carrier, a Seamen (E-3) isnâ€™t going to learn welding. They get out after 4 years and would have been better off going to a vocational school in the long run. There are more examples, that one just always stuck out to me.How many times did you say or hear, â€œif I knew then what I know now...â€ or, â€œif I ran into my recruiter...â€? 

I think knowing the actual jobs and what they ACTUALLY translate to in the civilian world would arm the young men and women with important knowledge! 

Thatâ€™s my opinion. Itâ€™s not ROTC-like, but I think that is more important to learn than â€˜military bearingâ€™, thatâ€™s what boot camp is for. I also saw a few responses about camping, knots, etc. Thatâ€™s the Boy Scouts. Any camping I did in the Army or Navy, had nothing to do with the Army or Navy! Only Boatswains Mates or Parachute Riggers need to know knots and that brings us back to my original point, know what the job translates to in the civilian world. PRâ€™s are who you bring your uniforms to after you get promoted to sew on your new rank. 

Some people want to do those jobs, bravo! If you are 21yo and want to prove yourself, to yourself, you may want to join â€˜Special Forcesâ€™. The â€™coolâ€™ movies arenâ€™t like reality and reality is boring, mind numbing, filled with â€œthatâ€™s not my job?!?â€.
